REZENSIONEN
K.  M.  T.  Chrimes : Ancient Sparta : a Re - examination of the Evidence.  Manchester University Press,  1949.  XV,  527 S. ,  10 Taf.  45 sh. 
I. 
A new book on Ancient Sparta,  upwards of five hundred pages in length,  is bound to attract the attention of ancient historians.  They will be well advised to read the Introduction first,  for in it the author explains the lines on which her book is planned.  As her purpose is »to make a study of later Sparta,  based mainly upon the epigraphical evidence,  the starting point for a fresh examination of the evidence about the earlier period «,  it is only natural that a chronological arrangement is precluded : and in any case the work »is not intended as a complete history of Sparta «.  The result is that we have to wait for chapter IX ( pp.  505 fF.  ) before we are introduced to Lycurgus,  and the main stages in the development of the constitution are discussed in the final chapter ( XI ). 
This novel line of approach,  together with the comprehensive scale of the book and the many controversial topics with which it deals,  invites us to summarize the contents at some length,  paying particular attention to the more controversial or unfamiliar portions of them. 
In chapter I »Relations with the Achaean League and Rome « the author re - examines the evidence for and against the survival of the characteristic Spartan institutions through the period extending from the reforms of Cleomenes III.  to the death of Nabis. 
She does not accept the account in Polybius of the extent to which Cleomenes suppressed the traditional elements of the constitution,  and discounts the value of the evidence in Livy and Plutarch for conditions at Sparta under the tyranny,  as being based on Polybius^s exaggerated picture of Nabis as the typical tyrant.  Similarly,  it is argued that the period of Achaean domination ( 188—179 B.  C.  ) was less destructive than Livy's words »Lycurgi leges moresque abrogarent« ( bk.  38,  с.  34 ) are usually taken to imply,  seeing that Plutarch only mentions the suppression of the Agoge,  which in any case was restored in 179 ( if not in 183 ).
